data.name: Nutrition for Sleep
data.description: Your evening meals may hold the key to better rest. Learn which foods promote relaxation and discover simple, sleep-friendly snack ideas to help you wind down and rest more deeply each night.
data.html:
What To Eat For Better Sleep

Sleep is vital for physical and mental wellbeing, yet many people struggle to get enough restful sleep each night. While sleep hygiene habits like limiting screen time and keeping a consistent bedtime are often recommended, one element that’s frequently overlooked is nutrition.

What you eat in the evening—particularly for your last meal or snack, can directly influence how easily you fall asleep and how well you stay asleep. Certain nutrients play a role in supporting the body’s natural sleep processes. Here’s a breakdown of what to focus on and some bedtime snack ideas to help you sleep more soundly.

 

Key Nutrients That Support Sleep

Melatonin: Melatonin is a hormone that regulates the sleep-wake cycle, also known as your circadian rhythm. While the body naturally produces melatonin, certain foods can offer a dietary boost.

Foods that contain melatonin:

  • Eggs
  • Nuts
  • Tart cherries

Incorporating these into your evening routine may support melatonin production and help prepare the body for sleep.

 

Serotonin (via Tryptophan): Serotonin is a brain chemical involved in mood and sleep regulation. It's a precursor to melatonin, meaning the body uses serotonin to create melatonin. While serotonin itself isn’t found in food, certain nutrients help the body produce it—most notably the amino acid tryptophan.

Foods rich in tryptophan:

  • Turkey
  • Poultry
  • Meat
  • Fish
  • Eggs
  • Dairy
  • Oats
  • Honey
  • Chickpeas

These foods can support serotonin production, which in turn helps with deeper and more restful sleep.

 

Calcium: Calcium supports muscle relaxation and nerve function and plays a role in helping the body settle down for rest.

Calcium-rich foods include:

  • Dairy products
  • Tofu
  • White beans
  • Sesame seeds
  • Almonds
  • Canned salmon (with bones)

If you take a calcium supplement, consider taking it before bed to support overnight sleep quality.

 

Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 helps maintain stable levels of serotonin and melatonin. A variety of whole foods provide this important nutrient.

Sources of vitamin B6:

  • Bananas
  • Potatoes
  • Poultry
  • Tuna
  • Fortified cereals
  • Spinach

Including B6-rich foods in your dinner or evening snack may help support your body’s natural rhythms.

 

Evening Snack Ideas

If you’re someone who benefits from a light snack before bed, here are a few combinations that include the sleep-supportive nutrients mentioned above:

  • Whole grain toast with almond butter and honey
  • Plain yogurt with tart cherries and oats
  • Banana with a few walnuts
  • Small bowl of oatmeal with cinnamon and milk
  • Turkey roll-up with a slice of cheese

 

Sleep starts with the habits and signals you give your body during the day—and your evening plate can play a powerful role. By making thoughtful food choices that support your body’s natural chemistry, you can ease into deeper, more restorative rest.
